ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained a deeper understanding of Astrophysics and Astronomy.
Intro to astrophysics, stellar evolution and astronomical measurements and instruments.
I learned about stellar evolution, the sun, and astronomical methods of observation.
An introductory knowledge of stellar astronomy
In taking this class, I learned a lot about the basics of astronomy and the mathematics accompanying the rationale astronomers have.

This class begins with astronomy fundamentals around measurements and physics, and then covers a star's lifecycle and collapse. We also discussed observational techniques, a brief history of astronomy and modern discoveries related to stars and black holes.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Relatively basic foundational course; not the most interesting but probably shouldn't change much.
Everything is very well explained. Online resources were very useful, and the homework was engaging and corresponded with what was taught in class.

A strength of this course is the organized structure of it with quizzes throughout the semester to keep students engaged with material that replaces a midterm, with just a final at the end being a summation of the quizzes and class material. A weakness could be the lecture format of the class which could become disengaging and more practice problems or discussion of the material in class could fix.
Honestly an all around good course, no complaints! Material is interesting, psets, exams, and workloads felt fair, and lectures are interesting.
This course is an excellent mix of understanding challenging concepts while also seeing results that actual astronomers have found.

Strengths: this class is well-paced and organized. All material needed is covered in lectures, and lecture slides are posted to Canvas. As someone who previously took a physics course, I found the class approachable but regardless of your background there are ample opportunities to ask questions and receive help.

Weaknesses: the lectures can be quite dry, but this is likely a result of needing to cover a broad range of material at an introductory level. Because of the limited math and physics prerequisites, this course does not go into many derivations of results, so there always remain some mystery around why certain formulas work.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student! You learn incredibly interesting information!
Yes. Astronomy is a cool subject, regardless of your major. Work is relatively easy, and the math mostly just requires identifying the right equation to use and plugging in the numbers.

Yes! it is very easy to follow what is taught in class, the content is interesting and the TA's help a lot during office hours if you are struggling. It is generally not as fast-paced as most other science courses.

I would recommend this course to another student if they are at all interested in astronomy and primarily stars. This course is not a math-heavy course at all with very simple algebra being used the whole time, it is mainly learning concepts and definitions that explain most of what we know about stars.
Yes! This is a fun, chill course - you will learn a lot. So long as you're comfortable with basic physics and geometry, you will do well.
I would. This course is taught by a passionate professor and shares a great insight into stars.

I would recommend this class to students who have an interest in astronomy, major or non-major. There is no significant physics or math background for this class, and the lectures, assignments, and exams are clear and straightforward. It is also important to highlight that this class opts for quizzes every two weeks in lieu of a midterm. We also had a night-time observatory trip, which was cold but fun!
